abstract.text: Please cite this article as: Sohail, A., Nutini, A., Forecasting the timeframe of coronavirus and human cells interaction with reverse engineering, Progress in Biophysics and Molecular Biology (2020), doi: https://doi.Abstract 6

body_text.text: worldwide emergency requiring the creation of new antiviral therapies and a related vaccine. The purpose 11 of this article is to review and investigate further the molecular mechanism by which the SARS-CoV2 12 virus infection proceeds via the formation of a hetero-trimer between its protein S, the ACE2 receptor 13 and the B0AT1 protein, which is the "entry receptor" for the infection process involving membrane "animal to man" and then "man to man " transmission. In December 2019, atypical pneumonia invaded 49 the city of Wuhan, China, and the causative agent of this disease was identified as a new coronavirus that 50 has been subsequently sequenced by five independent laboratories in China (http://www.virological.org).

In January 2020, the World Health Organization named the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV and subsequently 52 referred to it as SARS-CoV2 with its related disease referred to as CoViD-19 (Lai et al., 2020) .

Very soon, the epidemic created a pandemic, which is still progressing due to the human mobility The Secto ectodomain, which has two subunits: a subunit-anti-receptor called S1 and a subunit S2 with 79 strong lithic action, (defined as lysis of the host cell membrane to carry out the virus-host fusion and 80 start the infectious process) fuses the virus with the membrane, allowing the viral genome to enter the 81 host. A crosstalk between S1 and S2 then activates the pre-fusion conformation, activating S2 itself. The 82 S1 subunit can be further divided into four core domains: S1a, S1b, S1c and S1d.

Subunit S1 contains RBD (Receptor Binding Domain), which binds to the ACE-2 protein (angiotensin-84 converting enzyme 2) of the host cell membrane (on the surface of respiratory cells), which, in turn 85 functions as a receptor for the ligand (anti-receptor) constituted by the RBD domain itself. SARS-CoV 86 and SARS-CoV2 share 77.5% similarity in the amino acid sequence of S1. As mentioned above, viral 87 entry in the host requires S protein priming by cellular proteases, which involve S protein cleavage in S1

The binding with the ACE-2 protein occurs at the core domains S1a and this complex (ACE-2 + 97 S1a) makes the reaction irreversible. During this research, we have used the Hill function formalism to 98 illustrate the ligand-protein binding process. Details are provided in section 3. ACE-2, on the host cell 99 membrane, is usually connected to another protein called B 0 AT1. SARS-CoV2 infection begins with the 100 initial formation of a hetero trimer consisting of the RBD domain of the S1 subunit, from ACE-2 protein showing a cross reactivity with S1 subunits. Among these hybridomas, the one called 47D11 showed 117 neutralization activity for both SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV2 and targeted the RBD domain of S1b. binding that CoViD-19 shows in the infection process as described above. Our hypothesis is supported by 128 the need for activation of the infection system by the virus, given by the particular molecular kinetics that 129 leads to the formation of the "infection trimer" given by the viral S1 protein and the ACE-2 receptor While developing the computational framework, the virus-target cell interaction was studied in depth.

For this purpose, Hill function formalism, which helps to depict the dynamical behaviour and the biochemical interactions, is utilized. The model development can be understood with the aid of the schematic presented in figure 3 . A standard mathematical description of this function is given as:
A computational framework to interpret the dynamics of viral infection is presented in this manuscript.

The motivation behind the model development was to address the challenges linked with the fact that • determine/ forecast parametric values that will govern the dynamics of the mathematical model. 198 This "cytokine storm, causes the immune system to stat sending cells ready to do battle into the lung. 3. The reverse engineering approach proves to be efficient in parametric approximation for such com-220 plex dynamics. responsible for the interaction rates. Currently, the pandemic is ongoing. The model described here can 229 be implemented to future laboratory generated cell data.

FIGREF0.text: 14 fusion (Li et al., 2003). A reverse engineering process uses the formalism of the Hill function to represent 15 the functions related to the dynamics of the biochemical interactions of the viral infection process. Then, 16 using a logical evaluation of viral density that measures the rate at which the cells are hijacked by the 17 virus (and they provide a place for the virus to replicate) and considering the time delay given by the 18 interaction between cell and virus, the expected duration of the incubation period is predicted. The 19 conclusion is that the density of the virus varies from the exposure time to the interaction time (virus-20 cells). This model can be used both to evaluate the infectious condition and to analyze the incubation threat of the new coronavirus SARS-CoV2 pandemic is alarming and strategies for combating 24 infection are highly desired. This RNA virus belongs to the β-coronavirus genus and is similar in some 25 features to SARS-CoV. Currently, no vaccine or approved medical treatment is available. The complex 26 dynamics of the rapid spread of this virus can be demonstrated with the aid of a computational framework. 27 Methods: 28 A mathematical model based on the principles of cell-virus interaction is developed in this manuscript. 29 The amino acid sequence of S proein and its interaction with the ACE-2 protein is mimicked with the 30 aid of Hill function. The mathematical model with delay is solved with the aid of numerical solvers and 31 Preprint submitted to Elsevier the parametric values are obtained with the help of MCMC algorithm. differential equation model is developed to demonstrate the dynamics of target cells, infected 34 cells and the SARS-CoV2. The important parameters and coefficients are demonstrated with the aid of 35 numerical computations. The resulting thresholds and forecasting may prove to be useful tools for future 36 experimental studies and control strategies.

FIGREF1.text: analysis, I is concluded that control strategy via delay is a promising technique and the role of 39 Hill function formalism in control strategies can be better interpreted in an inexpensive manner with the 40 aid of a theoretical framework. 41 Keywords: SARS-CoV2, dynamical analysis, kinetic modelling, numerical simulations, monoclonal 42 antibody, MCMC analysis.

FIGREF2.text: CoV) is a pathogen that infects humans and other vertebrates; more precisely, it infects 45 the respiratory system, the gastrointestinal tract, the hepatic and nervous systems of humans, birds, 46 bats, mice and other animals. The SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) epidemic of 2002 and the 47 MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome) of 2012 demonstrated the spill over event of this virus, first in 48

FIGREF3.text: 54 that took place in early 2020. A severe outbreak was subsequently reported in Italy (and now extensive 55 outbreaks are also registered in Iran, France, Germany, Spain, UK, USA and elsewhere), resulting in an 56 emergency situation, to impose containment measures of a kind not recently reported, where civilians 57 have been kept in forced quarantine and the commercial services were "locked down"; this is now a 58 worldwide emergency and for this reason the creation of new antiviral therapies and related vaccines is 59 urgently needed, based upon a possible functional model of this virus.

FIGREF4.text: understand the infectious nature of this coronavirus SARS-CoV2 (RNA virus), it is necessary 62 to understand its structure. The virus belongs to the beta-coronavirus genus and is closely related to 63 another virus of the same family known as SARS-CoV but, unlike this, SARS-CoV2 has a higher degree of 64 transmission between humans (Wu et al., 2020). SARS-CoV2 has a multifunctional molecular mechanism 65 associated with an envelope with three structural proteins (glycoproteins): M protein (membrane protein), 66 E protein (envelope protein), S protein (that directly mediates the hosts infection) and N protein (viral 67 RNA binding). The structure is presented in figures 1 and 2 respectively.

FIGREF5.text: of disease transmission depends on the spike protein (S-protein as shown in figure 70 1). This protein binds the virus in reaction catalysed by the host cells surface enzymes. Recent gene 71 analysis (Coutard et al., 2020) helped to distinguish between the characteristics of the SARS-CoV2 S 72 proteins and those of SARS-CoV, mainly referring to a cleavage site peculiar to the furin enzyme (found 73 in CoViD-19 and not in other CoVs). SARS-CoV2 infects the host and gains the protein S

FIGREF6.text: 88and S2 subunits where the S2 subunit allows the fusion of viral and cellular membranes; the S protein of89 SARS-CoV engages ACE-2 as the entry-receptor Li et al. (2003) and employs the cellular serine-protease 90 TMPRSS2 for S-priming (Glowacka et al., 2011). Due to the high percentage identity of amino-acid 91 sequence between SARS-CoV S-protein and SARS-CoV2 S-protein, it is highly possible that both SARS 92 viruses use the same serine-protease. The linking to ACE-2 for virus entry infection shows high efficiency 93 in its function and this is a possibly a major factor of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV2 high transmissibility 94 (Li et al., 2005). Is also possible that a TMPRSS2-inhibitor, approved for clinical use, blocks entry of 95 the virus and constitutes a treatment option (Hoffmann et al., 2020).

FIGREF7.text: in its PD domain) and B 0 AT1 protein. For future research, this trimeric complex can be explored and 102 manipulated. A study conducted by (Wrapp et al., 2020) suggests that ACE-2 must dimerise to become 103 activate, resulting in two PD homo-dimer domains capable of binding the SARS-CoV2 S protein and 104 forming a trimer. Furthermore, they reported that SARS-CoV2 protein S forms trimers with two of the 105 RBD domains: one facing upwards and one facing downwards. This structure is presented in figure 2. 106 Researchers around the world are making every effort to develop a vaccine against the virus, for 107 example a recent study reported the dependence of SARS-CoV-2 cell entry on ACE2 (Hoffmann et al., 108 2020). The molecular bond between SARS-CoV2 spike protein and ACE2 looks similar to that of the 109 SARS-CoV, but there are some differences in the precise amino acids used to bind SARS-CoV2 to that 110 ACE2 receptor compared to SARS-CoV. Most likely the high affinity, probably derived from such small 111 variations of 2019-nCoV S protein for human ACE2, may contribute to the apparent ease with which 112 2019-nCoV can spread from human to human (Wrapp et al., 2020). Recently, (Wang et al., 2020) have 113 discussed the possibility of using a monoclonal antibody as an antiviral therapy: i.e. 47D11 antibody that 114 targets the trimeric complex involving glycoprotein S. In this research, tests performed by the ELISA 115 cross-reactivity system with S1-SARS-S hybridomas in supernatant indicated four types of hybridomas 116

FIGREF8.text: Wang et al. (2020) showed that 47D11 has a greater affinity for the ectodomain of the S 119 (Secto) protein of SARS-CoV than SARS-CoV2, despite the antigen being present in equimolar amounts.120This bond, however, does not compete with the binding of S1b with ACE-2. 47D11 is included among the 121 monoclonal antibodies that can inactivate the "S-protein" of SARS-CoV2 by preventing the formation of122 the pre-fusion structure (Walls et al., 2019). A further structural analysis has shown that S1b core domain 123 can be divided into a core subdomain of about 338-506 amino acids and a receptor-binding subdomain 124 of about 438-498 amino acids; the latter consists of a loop protruding from the -sheet structure of the 125 core subdomain. Currently, the inhibition mechanism operated by 47D11 is not understood. Thus in this 126 review we investigate through a quantitative mathematical model, the possible existence of a cooperative 127

Some studies have shown the possibility of an analysis in this sense conducted through the 131 Hill function and have shown a "positive cooperativity" in the case of infection of para-flu viruses that 132 act by binding with a Hemagglutinin-Neuraminidase Receptor (Tappert et al., 2013). The interaction, 133 demonstrated by 47D11 monoclonal antibody, does not affect the bond between the protein S and ACE-134 2 but has affinity with the RBD domain of the same protein S, suggesting that there is a facilitation 135 implying an amplification of the process that, in turn, causes an increase in the infection capacity. Section 3 provides the discussion based on the facts linked with the novel virus 141 onset. The conclusions and future work are provided after the discussion.

FIGREF14.text: Schematic description of the disease dynamics.SARS-CoV2 lack self-sufficiency, i.e. it is a dormant particle unless it enters a host cell, where it hijacks 162 the metabolism of host cell and produces copies of itself. Therefore for scientific research, such as for 163 vaccine development, it is difficult to culture it and a computational framework can provide a better 164 opportunity to explore the dynamics of the infection.165    Two important questions about the disease onset are: 166 1. Infectious Dose: amount of SARS-CoV2 virus, the host is exposed to.167 2. Incubation Period: time taken by the virus to hijack the target cells.168To address the questions one by one, we have run some numerical experiments based on the set of parametric values (source files provided as supplementary material). First, we focused on the infectious dose Shen and Woo (2020), i.e. the amount of virus, the host was exposed to. From the mathematical model presented in section 2, we can see that the density V of SARS-CoV2 depends on the term:c 1 I(t − τ 2 ) since S are obligate intracellular pathogens ( they can replicate depending on the metabolism of a host 169 cell), c 1 is the parameter that measures the rate at which the infected cells are hijacked by the virus and 170 provide a place to replicate the virus. The density V also depends on the delay caused by the infected 171 cell and virus interaction, represented as τ 2 . The concept of delay in cell interactions and its growth 172 is not new and dates back in 2002, when "Interaction of the Coronavirus Nucleoprotein with Nucleolar 173 Antigens and the Host Cell" was reported by Chen et al. (2002).174In general, developing the mathematical models for biological problems is really challenging since it 175 is really important to176    • determine the structure of the biological problem through system of differential equations, Visualization of repeated virus attacks.

FIGREF16.text: The two points are the central issues of computational systems biology. This type of approach ia 179 also considered as a "reverse engineering process" (Zhan and Yeung, 2011). The parameter estimation180 problem is generally formulated as an optimization problem that minimizes an objective function which 181 represents the fitness of the model with respect to a set of experimental data. For the given problem, 182 since the experimental data is not available yet, we have used MCMC to forecast the parametric values 183 based on the research hypothesis and evidence available in the recent literature.184 In this manuscript we have obtained the most appropriate value for the parameter c 1 with the aid of 185 MCMC (Markov chain Monte Carlo) reverse engineering tool of Matlab T M . FIGREF17.text: It is reported in the literature( Reddy and Sansom (2016)) that the immune response and the virus then200 work together to damage the body of the infected host. This effect is presented in table 1, where we can 201 see the negative sign with the treatment term, when the model was analyzed using reverse engineering 202 based on the reported studies.203 To explore the resulting density of virus after interaction with the human cells, we have varied the 204 parametric values (for increased and reduced interaction scenarios) and have showed in figure 5 that the 205 time taken by the virus to hijack target cells and to convert these into infected cells was really short when 206 the exposure to virus was increased (right panel), whereas it took almost double the time in disease onset 207 when the interaction was limited. 208 Next, the Hill function coefficient "Hill" was varied for below and above 1/2 to check the dynamics 209 of the disease. We can see from figure 6 out of phase dynamics with different periods of interaction. The 210 left panel shows the dynamics in interaction and the right panel provides the phase space portraits for 211 virus and infected cells densities. Figure 7 depicts the density of infected cells relative to time for equal 212 and different values of delays for target cells, virus (τ 1 ) and infected cells (τ 2 ). Figure 8 provides the clear 213 understanding of the spread of infection relative to different values of parameter b (1). 214 With the aid of mathematical model we have concluded the following: 215 1. Delay from one compartment to the other plays an important role in the timeframe of the disease 216 onset. 217 2. The Hill function is important in kinetic modeling and the Hill coefficient is important parameter 218 to forecast a complete cycle of infection. For different values of the coefficient "Hill", helpful dynamics in disease onset are depicted. For different values of the coefficient "Hill", helpful dynamics in disease onset are depicted. For different values of the coefficient "b", helpful dynamics in disease onset are depicted.

FIGREF18.text: presents a computational framework to explore the dynamics of novel SARS-CoV2 223 onset. The model helps to analyze the time period required by the virus to hijack the cells and spread 224 through the body by infecting the target cells. Emphasis is made in this manuscript on the accurate un-225 derstanding of the delay in "target cell-SARS-CoV2" interaction, which can help to forecast the expected 226 duration of incubation period. It is concluded that the density of virus varies from the exposure time (of 227 virus to the target cells) to interaction time. This variation can be monitored through the parameters 228
